Hi Company_A—Seeker_E here. Per your request, here’s one concise example that best matches the “owned the critical path, hard deadline” signal:

Project: Cross-functional launch of a new operational workflow + tooling integration for a time-sensitive partner rollout.

My role: DRI/PM for the critical path—owned the plan, milestones, and tradeoffs; ran weekly exec/working-team cadences; drove alignment across Eng, Ops, Legal/Compliance, and Support; managed risk/issue escalation and dependency tracking.
Key dependencies: (1) Eng delivery of integration + data validation, (2) Ops readiness/training and SOP creation, (3) Legal/compliance sign-off, (4) Support playbooks and comms.
Outcome/metrics: Hit the hard deadline; launched with no Sev-1 incidents in the first 30 days; reduced manual handling time ~30% (via the new workflow) and improved on-time processing by ~15% within the first month post-launch.

If circumstances change on your side for this seat (or a closely related scope), I’m ready to move fast and commit. Hi Company_A—Seeker_E here. Thanks for the direct feedback; happy to clarify:

1) Team size/seniority + decision authority:
- Core team I was driving: ~6 engineers (mix of mid + 1 senior/tech lead) plus ~8–10 Ops stakeholders (incl. an Ops lead/manager) and 1 Legal/Compliance partner; Support lead + 2 SMEs for readiness.
- There were EM/Eng leads involved (EM + tech lead). I did not have unilateral “ship/no-ship” authority, but I *did* have explicit authority to recommend scope-cuts/tradeoffs and to escalate risks; final ship decision was made in the go/no-go with EM + business owner, and my critical-path status + readiness criteria were the basis for that call.

2) What was technically-adjacent on my end:
- I owned the PRD/spec and acceptance criteria, defined data requirements/validation rules with Eng, and wrote the end-to-end workflow + edge cases.
- I ran technical/design reviews to align on approach, coordinated QA/UAT (test plan + sign-offs), and managed release readiness (cutover plan, monitoring/alerts checklist, rollback considerations).
- I didn’t code, but I was hands-on in translating requirements into implementable tickets and ensuring the integration met the agreed API/data contract.

Given this, would you route me toward this exact seat if it reopens, or do you think a neighboring scope/team would be a better fit for how you’re staffing the immediate need?
